title: Issue 43, October 25, 2022
author: Show Abstract
cleaned_text: Issue 43, October 25, 2022 CDC Science Clips: Volume 14, Issue 43, October 25, 2022 Welcome to CDC [Science Clips](https://www.cdc.gov/library/sciclips/index.html), CDC's weekly publications digest. This week, Science Clips is pleased to feature articles related to the new CDC Vital Signs on [Inequities in Flu Vaccine Uptake: More Vaccination Needed for People from Some Racial/Ethnic Groups](https://www.cdc.gov/vitalsigns/flu-inequities/index.html) Flu vaccination is the best way to protect against flu. Vaccination may not always prevent infection, but it can make symptoms less severe and reduce the risk of being hospitalized. Flu vaccination coverage has been consistently lower among Black, Hispanic, and AI/AN adults. There are many reasons for these inequities, including lack of access to health care and insurance, missed opportunities to vaccinate, and misinformation and distrust. Increasing equitable vaccine uptake requires addressing the range of reasons why people do not get vaccinated. Over the past two years, CDC has begun two programs to address vaccination barriers and raise awareness about the importance of flu vaccination, specifically among people from racial and ethnic minority groups: the [Partnering for Vaccine Equity (P4VE)](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/health-equity/index.html) program and a targeted [flu vaccination campaign](https://getmyflushot.org/). The report consists of these components: [Key scientific articles in featured topic areas](#KeyArticles)(this week featuring CDC authored editorials and scientific publications focused on inequities in flu vaccine uptake.) [CDC-authored publications](#CDCAuthors) - CDC Vital Signs - Inequities in Flu Vaccine Uptake - [Flu activity & surveillance](https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/fluactivitysurv.htm) CDC.
